journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Arthroscopic Bone Marrow Stimulation Techniques for Osteochondral Lesions of the Talus
title-group.subtitle: Prognostic Factors for Small Lesions

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Fukuoka University, Fukuoka, Japan

author-notes.corresp: *Ichiro Yoshimura, MD, PhD, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Faculty of Medicine, Fukuoka University, 7-45-1 Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka 814-0180, Japan (e-mail: ichiroy813@gmail.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The defect size of an osteochondral lesion of the talus is one of the most important prognostic factors for deciding clinical outcomes. However, the prognostic factors for small osteochondral lesions of the talus are unknown.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To investigate the significant prognostic factors for small osteochondral lesions of the talus using arthroscopic bone marrow stimulation techniques.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Fifty ankles in 50 patients treated with arthroscopic bone marrow stimulation techniques for an osteochondral lesion of the talus (<150 mm2) were evaluated for prognostic factors. The patients were 22 men and 28 women (mean age, 35.0 years). Outcomes were measured using the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) Ankle-Hindfoot Scale, Berndt and Harty scale, and Saxena criteria.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The mean lesion size was 62 mm2 (range, 7-119 mm2). The mean AOFAS score improved from 74 (range, 18-90) preoperatively to 90 (range, 67-100) postoperatively. The Saxena criteria results were excellent, good, fair, and poor in 36 (72%), 8 (16%), 5 (10%), and 1 (2%) patients, respectively. The Berndt and Harty scale results were good in 34 (68%), fair in 6 (12%), and poor in 10 (20%) patients. Linear regression analyses showed prognostic significance for lesion depth and outcome. Medial lesions had a significantly higher incidence of poor outcomes than lateral lesions (P < .05). Among the medial lesions, lesions uncovered with the medial malleolus had inferior outcomes compared with covered lesions (P < .0001). There was no association between clinical outcome and lesion size or body mass index. In older patients (≥40 years), there was a significant trend toward inferior clinical outcomes (P < .05).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Arthroscopic bone marrow stimulation techniques provided satisfactory clinical outcomes. However, older patients, deep lesions, and medial lesions uncovered with the medial malleolus were associated with inferior clinical outcomes.

body.p: An osteochondral lesion of the talus (OLT) is a common cause of ankle pain and disability in people with a wide age range. The treatment options for this condition vary and include nonsurgical and surgical approaches according to the lesion characteristics. However, nonsurgical treatments have been reported to be associated with low success rates.42,44 Thus, symptomatic lesions frequently require surgery. The operative treatments for this condition include excision, excision and curettage, excision with curettage and drilling (ECD), excision with curettage and microfracture (ECM), osteochondral grafting, iliac bone grafting, and autologous chondrocyte implantation.‖ Arthroscopic bone marrow stimulation (ABMS) techniques include ECD and ECM and have become established procedures for OLTs. However, several factors were reported to affect the clinical outcome after ABMS.¶ For example, ankle instability, global lesions, increasing age, lesion location, higher body mass index (BMI), and larger lesions have been reported to negatively affect the clinical outcome.

A few reports mention lesion size as an important prognostic factor for clinical outcome.8,10,11,16,17 The cited articles defined cutoff points (area size, 150 mm2 or 1.5 cm2; diameter, 15 mm) for the lesion size regarding the risk of clinical failure. Choi et al8 investigated the lesion size of OLTs in 120 patients on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The mean area size was 111.73 ± 54.98 mm2 (coronal length, 10.47 ± 2.57 mm; sagittal length, 12.33 ± 4.14 mm; depth, 5.77 ± 2.45 mm). In 79% of patients, the lesion areas were <150 mm2. However, the prognostic factors for smaller lesions (<150 mm2) were not clarified in the previous studies.8,10,11,16,17 The purpose of this study was to investigate the significant prognostic factors for small OLTs treated with ABMS techniques. We hypothesized that the outcomes of small OLTs are affected by variable factors.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Sixty patients (62 ankles) with OLTs were treated by arthroscopic procedures involving drilling, ECD, and ECM from October 2005 to December 2011. All 62 ankles were treated by 3 experienced surgeons. For the purpose of this study, 12 ankles were excluded: those with lesions of ≥150 mm2 (5%; 3 ankles), global lesions (3%; 2 ankles), or those treated by drilling alone (8%; 5 ankles); and ankles with lesions of ≥150 mm2 and treated by drilling (3%; 2 ankles). Overall, 92% were small lesions from October 2005 to December 2011. The remaining 50 ankles in 50 patients were defined by our criteria (ECD, 38 ankles; ECM, 12 ankles) by analysis of the medical records. All cases were evaluated preoperatively and at 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, and annually postoperatively. The patients did not attend scheduled follow-ups, and the information was collected by telephone interviews. All the patients had primary lesions and localized defects on the talar dome, with ankle pain or functional limitations despite nonsurgical treatment for at least 4 months, including rest, bracing, immobilization, anti-inflammatory medication, and physical therapy. The mean duration of preoperative symptoms was 12.7 months (range, 4-120 months). Thirty-nine ankles had an ankle trauma history, and 11 ankles did not. The clinical criteria for exclusion were arthritic changes of the ankle on plain radiographs.

The patients were investigated for their pretreatment and posttreatment scores according to the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) Ankle-Hindfoot Scale, Berndt and Harty scale,5 and Saxena criteria34 (excellent, 90-100; good, 80-89; fair, 70-79; poor, <70).

For each patient, plain radiographs and MRI scans of the ankle were obtained to confirm the diagnosis and to identify any other associated lesions. The lesions were graded by the revised classification of Hepple et al.19 The stages were as follows: stage 1, articular cartilage damage only; stage 2a, cartilage injury with underlying fracture and surrounding bony edema; stage 2b, stage 2a without surrounding bony edema; stage 3, detached but undisplaced fragment; stage 4, detached and displaced fragment; and stage 5, subchondral cyst formation. The location and size of each osteochondral lesion were collected from the MRI findings. The defect area size was defined and determined for each patient on the MRI scans according to Choi et al6-8: coronal length (horizontal extension measured on the coronal image), sagittal length (horizontal extension measured on the sagittal image), depth (vertical extension measured on the coronal image), and area (calculated by the ellipse formula of coronal length × sagittal length × 0.79).

The medial lesions were divided into 2 groups of covered and uncovered lesions on the MRI scans (coronal images) (Figure 1). A covered lesion was defined as a lesion that was completely covered by the articular surface of the medial malleolus. An uncovered lesion was defined as a lesion in which the medial edge of the base of the lesion was over the articular surface of the medial malleolus.

caption.p: (A) Covered lesion. The lesion is covered with the articular surface of the medial malleolus on magnetic resonance imaging. (B) Uncovered lesion. The lesion is over the distal end of the medial malleolus.

sec.p: Our institutional review board approved the study protocol.

sec.title: Operative Treatment
sec.p: All patients underwent arthroscopic ECD or ECM, as described by Steadman et al37 and Takao et al,40 respectively. In all patients, arthroscopic synovectomy was performed simultaneously. Patients with ankle instability underwent ankle ligament repair or reconstruction concurrently with modified Broström procedures.14 Patients subjected to ABMS alone did not require postoperative immobilization. On the day after surgery, these patients were advised to perform exercises to increase their range of motion and were maintained as nonweightbearing for a period of 2 weeks, followed by partial weightbearing for 4 weeks, before resuming full weightbearing. Thirteen patients with simultaneous ankle ligament surgery were immobilized with a short leg splint for 1 week postoperatively, followed by a cast for 2 weeks, before immobilization with a soft ankle orthosis for 10 weeks. At 3 weeks after surgery, active range of motion was allowed. Also at 3 weeks after surgery, partial weightbearing and strengthening exercises were allowed with a soft ankle orthosis for 4 weeks, before resuming full weightbearing. For all patients, jogging was allowed at 12 weeks after surgery, and return to sports or high-impact activities was allowed from 4 to 6 months postoperatively dependent on the muscle strength.8,10

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The potential prognostic factors investigated were as follows: age, BMI, area of lesion, depth of lesion, location of lesion, covering of a medial lesion with the medial malleolus, procedures (ECD/ECM), and lateral ligament repair. Preoperative and postoperative differences in quantitative data were evaluated by the Mann-Whitney U test, while preoperative and postoperative differences in qualitative data were evaluated by the χ2 test. The Mann-Whitney U test was used to determine whether there were significant differences between 2 categorical variables of lesion location (lateral or medial), BMI ≥25, covering of a medial lesion (covered or uncovered), ligament repair (with or without), procedures (ECM or ECD), and age ≥40 years. The Kruskal-Wallis test was used to compare mean values among 3 groups (Berndt and Harty scale; good, fair, and poor results) for variables. Pearson correlation was used to determine whether symptom duration, lesion size, and lesion depth were related to treatment outcomes. The level of significance for all statistical tests was set at P < .05. The statistical analyses were performed using Prism software version 5.0 (GraphPad Software Inc, La Jolla, California). All data are reported as the mean ± standard deviation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The mean age at surgery was 35 years (range, 12-77 years). There were 22 men and 28 women. The mean follow-up duration was 36.3 months (range, 7-72 months). The mean lesion size was 62 mm2 (range, 7-119 mm2), and mean lesion depth was 4.7 mm (range, 2-8 mm). The mean BMI was 23.8 (range, 18.7-32.7). The distribution of MRI stages was Hepple stage 1 in 1 patient, stage 2a in 3 patients, stage 2b in 1, stage 3 in 32, stage 4 in 5, and stage 5 in 8 patients. The mean AOFAS score improved from 74 (range, 18-90) preoperatively to 90 (range, 67-100) postoperatively (P < .0001). The Saxena criteria results were excellent, good, fair, and poor in 36 (72%), 8 (16%), 5 (10%), and 1 (2%) patients, respectively. The Berndt and Harty scale results were good in 34 (68%), fair in 6 (12%), and poor in 10 patients (20%). Four patients (8%) required revision surgery (bone graft, 3 ankles; re-ABMS, 1 ankle) because of either persistent or recurrent pain for 1 year after the initial surgery (ECD). Three patients underwent iliac bone grafting owing to cystic changes at the base of the lesion at the drilling site. No complications, such as deep infection, were observed.

The lesion area had no association with the AOFAS score (r = −0.04, P = .75). The lesion depth had a weak association with the AOFAS score (r = −0.386, P = .0057). In addition, there was a significant difference for lesion depth in the Berndt and Harty scale (P = .0052) (Table 1). The OLT locations were as follows: medial, 40 (80%) (centromedial, 6; posteromedial, 34); and lateral, 10 (20%) (anterolateral, 5; contralateral, 1; posterolateral, 4). There was a significant difference in the postoperative AOFAS scores between the medial and lateral lesions (medial: 89.3 ± 9.4; lateral: 95.8 ± 6.9; P = .024) (Table 2). On the contrary, there was no significant difference in the Berndt and Harty scale findings (P = .2). However, all 10 ankles classified as poor were medial lesions. Furthermore, in the medial lesions, a significant difference in the clinical outcome was observed between the covered and uncovered lesions (AOFAS score: covered lesions, 91.6 ± 8.1; uncovered lesions, 78.1 ± 9.8; P < .00001) (Berndt and Harty scale: P < .0001; Saxena criteria: P = .00018) (Table 3). In older patients, there was a significant trend toward inferior clinical outcomes (AOFAS score: <40 years, 93.7 ± 7.9; ≥40 years, 85.6 ± 9.2; P = .0023). Body mass index was not found to be related to the clinical outcome (AOFAS score: <25, 91.8 ± 8.2; ≥25, 86.3 ± 10.7; P = .062). The symptom duration had no association with the AOFAS score (r = −0.12, P = .39).

caption.p: Comparisons of Age, Lesion Depth, Lesion Size, Lesion Location, and Clinical Outcome by the Berndt and Harty Scalea

sec.p: There was a significant difference in the clinical outcomes between ankles with and without ligament repair (AOFAS score: with ligament repair, 98.2 ± 3.9; without ligament repair, 88.0 ± 9.0; P = .006) (Berndt and Harty scale: P = .04; Saxena criteria: P = .03). However, there were no significant differences for age (P = .28), area size (P = .54), and depth (P = .23).

There was a significant difference in the AOFAS scores between ECM and ECD (ECM: 95.8 ± 6.7; ECD: 89.0 ± 9.1; P = .016). However, there were no significant differences in the Saxena criteria (P = .45) and Berndt and Harty scale (P = .18) results.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The ABMS techniques are defined as the first-line procedures for OLTs because several previous articles have reported good clinical outcomes.42,44 Recently, several prognostic factors were reported to affect clinical outcomes. Gobbi et al17 reported that there was an inverse relationship between OLT size and clinical outcome. Chuckpaiwong et al10 reported excellent results for microfractures when the defect was smaller than 15 mm in diameter. There were no treatment failures with lesions smaller than 15 mm in diameter. Increasing age, higher BMI, history of trauma, and presence of osteophytes negatively affected the outcome, while the presence of instability and anterolateral soft tissue scarring were correlated with a successful outcome. Choi et al8 demonstrated a relationship between the risk of clinical failure and defect area size of ≥150 mm2. Other factors such as age, symptom duration, trauma, associated lesions, and lesion location had no association with the outcome. Cuttica et al11 described that OLTs of >1.5 cm2 in area size were more likely to have inferior clinical outcomes than smaller OLTs. In addition, increasing age up to 33 years may have had an association with inferior outcomes.

A systematic review by Zengerink et al44 revealed an 85% success rate for ABMS. A cutoff point regarding the risk of clinical failure exists for a size of approximately 15-mm diameter or 150-mm2 area. Lesion size was the most powerful predictor of the clinical outcome. Arthroscopic bone marrow stimulation was identified as the best treatment option for OLTs of <15-mm diameter or <150-mm2 area. Christensen et al9 demonstrated that the lesion size may alter contact stress in the ankle and found significant changes in the contact characteristics for larger lesions (≥7.5 × 15 mm; P < .05). Their data supported the results of several articles investigating the relationship between clinical outcome and lesion size. However, a predictor was not clarified for small lesions (diameter, <15 mm; area, <150 mm2). Lee et al24 investigated the prognostic factors in isolated small osteochondral lesions. The lesion size, age, duration of symptoms, and BMI were not related to the clinical outcome in isolated OLTs (lesion size, <1.5 cm2; age, <50 years). In addition, longer symptom duration was found to negatively affect the outcome. However, the study only evaluated the prognostic factors for small lesions. In their study, 89% of patients achieved excellent or good results as determined by the AOFAS scoring system. These results24 are better than those in previous studies that included lesions of >15-mm diameter or >150-mm2 area.2,3,9,15,16

The lesion size is one of the most important prognostic factors. However, the lesion sizes were measured by various methods, such as electrically on MRI, intraoperatively, or manually with a ruler on plain radiographs.8,10,11,16,17 In addition, the sizes were defined by the diameter of the lesion or the sagittal length or area. Therefore, the measurement methods have not been standardized. The diameter and sagittal length provide information for a unidimensional measured base. Thus, the risk of clinical failure increases with increasing defect size. Magnetic resonance imaging provides excellent visualization of the cartilage, bone, and soft tissue on multiple slices and therefore shows not only the lesion size but also the lesion location and subchondral cysts.

No previous studies have investigated the differences between ECD and ECM. The clinical outcomes of ECD were reported in several articles. Tol et al42 reported that ECD is associated with a high percentage of excellent/good results (88%) in a systematic review. Recently, many articles have described excellent clinical outcomes of ECM.3,7,8,10,11,17,24,25 In fact, ECM is technically simple, has low morbidity, and is cost-effective.2 The most important advantage of ECM is the lack of risk of thermal necrosis during drilling. The difference in the clinical outcomes between ECD and ECM was not clear in our study. However, there were 4 cases that required additional surgery, and all 4 of these cases underwent ECD. In 3 of the 4 cases, cystic changes occurred at the drilling site of the talus. Ferkel et al15 reported the occurrence of cystic changes after ECD and recommended irrigation of the K-wire with cool saline to minimize the risk of thermal necrosis during drilling.

Osteochondral lesions of the talus can be present with chronic ankle instability.10,38,41 Controversy exists over the timing of surgical intervention in these patients with concomitant OLT and chronic ankle instability and whether both disorders should be addressed simultaneously. Few studies have addressed the treatment of OLTs in the setting of chronic instability.10,38,41 Schimmer et al35 noted that instability of the ankle might cause osteochondral lesions of the ankle and advocated that it should be corrected concurrently. In the present study, the clinical outcomes in the patients who underwent ABMS and ligament repair were superior to those in the patients who underwent ABMS only. Chuckpaiwong et al10 described that ankle pain may be caused by either anterolateral impingement or instability or the osteochondral lesion in patients with OLTs and ankle instability. Overall, 56.8% of the patients in the success group had anterolateral impingement compared with only 7% in the unsuccessful group. Takao et al41 investigated intra-articular disorders in cases of residual ankle disability after sprain with arthroscopic surgery. All of the cases examined here had some degree of serious synovitis. All of our cases underwent arthroscopic synovectomy simultaneously, which might have led to better outcomes. In patients with OLTs, range of motion exercises should be started as soon as possible after ABMS. On the other hand, several lateral ligament stabilization studies have suggested immobilization of the ankle for a period of time. In this study, differences in the protocol affected the clinical outcomes.

Our results suggested that age may play a role in the clinical outcome. There was an increasing possibility of an inferior outcome as age increased up to 40 years. The relationship between clinical outcome and increased age is a controversial issue. Previous in vitro studies have reported an age-related decline in the number of mesenchymal stem cells in the bone marrow.4,12 Several articles have reported inferior outcomes in older patients.9,16 On the contrary, Becher et al2 reported that the results for patients older than 50 years were not inferior to those for younger patients. Choi et al7 concluded that increased age was not an independent risk factor for a poor clinical outcome. However, in their study, older patients were more likely to have smaller osteochondral defects. In contrast, our study found that older patients had smaller and shallower lesions than younger patients, and a significant difference was demonstrated for the clinical outcome. It is surmised that increasing age affected the clinical outcome of ABMS for small lesions. It is necessary to perform a more in-depth longitudinal clinical analysis to further clarify the long-term clinical outcomes.

Choi et al8 reported that the depth of a cartilage defect was weakly associated with the clinical outcome. Subchondral cysts were deeper lesions than lesions without cysts. Cystic lesions were included in their cases (29.2%) that had an inferior outcome. In our series, only 8 cases (16%) had cystic lesions, but a weak correlation was still observed between lesion depth and outcome. The aim of ABMS is to fill the defects with fibrocartilage. Two articles described that the cartilage filling grade was correlated with the outcome.22,26 However, other articles described that MRI findings were not correlated with clinical assessment during the follow-up of OLTs.3,31 Recently, Kuni et al23 investigated the clinical state after arthroscopic microfracture and the MRI outcome in OLTs. The defect was totally refilled with repair tissue in 59% (13/22 ankles). In 2 cases, the defect disappeared completely, and the AOFAS scores were high (92 and 100 points). Our results suggested that it was easy to fill shallow lesions, while deep lesions were difficult because they were not adequately filled with blood clots, and the blood clots were not stabilized. However, we did not evaluate the amount or quality of fill with postoperative imaging.

The controversy regarding the significance of the lesion location has not been resolved. Some articles described that patients with medial lesions had a superior outcome over patients with lateral lesions.10,36 Conversely, another article reported that patients with lateral lesions had a better outcome.33 Several articles concluded that there was no significant difference in the clinical outcomes of patients with medial and lateral OLTs.2,3,7,8,11,24,25 However, the multivariate analyses in most of these articles indicated that the factors associated with the difference in clinical outcomes between patients with medial and lateral lesions included larger lesion size but did not exclude the effects of the most powerful prognostic factors. Chuckpaiwong et al10 described that lesion size was a confounding factor for location. A discrepancy was observed between our results and these previous articles. In our data, lesion size, lesion depth, and age were found to show no significant differences between medial and lateral lesions.

Biomechanical studies of ankle articular cartilage have shown that cartilage lesions such as OLTs may be related to the disparity of the mechanical properties in different regions of the ankle.1 The softest tissue in the talar dome appears to be on the posteromedial talar dome. Furthermore, stiffer articular cartilage is found on the tibial side than on the talar dome side. Most of the medial articular surface of the talus is covered with articular cartilage of the tibial plafond and medial malleolus. The ABMS technique consists of several steps, including debridement to a stable cartilage defect, removal of the calcified cartilage layer, and homogeneous placement of microfracture penetrations within the cartilage defect, with resultant complete defect filling by well-anchored mesenchymal stem cells.26

In osteochondral defects of the knee, several articles have described whether contained or uncontained lesions comprise an important factor affecting the clinical outcomes26-28 because the articular surface of the femorotibial joint has low congruity. Fortunately, the ankle joint possesses high congruency with anatomic structures, which leads to good clinical outcomes for ABMS in the ankle joint. Recently, however, 2 articles have investigated the relationship between the containment of the lesion and the clinical outcome. Cuttica et al11 described that uncontained lesions were associated with inferior outcomes. Choi et al6 concluded that patients with an uncontained OLT of the talar shoulder type experience a worse clinical outcome than patients with an uncontained OLT of the nonshoulder type, even after adjustment for OLT size and regardless of the location. It was surmised that lesions without a stable rim lose the protective border, thereby making stable formation of fibrocartilage less likely. In the present study, uncovered lesions were associated with inferior clinical outcomes for medial lesions. It was important that the lesions were surrounded by solid tissue, such as the base of the lesion and the articular surface of the tibia. Presumably, when a lesion is not surrounded by these solid tissues, clot filling of the defects and stabilization of the blood clots are hindered for repair of the osteochondral defects. This is the first study to evaluate the effect of covering with the medial malleolus on the clinical outcome after ABMS.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: A major limitation of the present study is the lack of postoperative MRI evaluation. Future research should include improved randomized controlled trials, long-term follow-up, greater numbers of patients, and postoperative MRI evaluation, which is steadily gaining wide acceptance among arthroscopic surgeons. However, this study identified prognostic factors for small OLTs treated with ABMS techniques.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The ABMS procedures are safe and efficient techniques that provide good clinical outcomes in 90% of patients with OLTs <150 mm2. However, older patients, deeper lesions, and uncovered lesions are often associated with inferior outcomes.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
